newsitem.title: CANADA: Canada bonds open almost flat on election results.
newsitem.headline: Canada bonds open almost flat on election results.

text.p: Canadian bonds opened North American trading almost unchanged on Tuesday after Canada's ruling Liberal government won just a narrow majority in yesterday's federal election.
While the bond market had been expected rally if the Liberals won a convincing majority, analysts said the narrow win gave the market little cause for celebration.
"Fiscally I don't think there are any changes but the slight majority might be reining in enthusiasm," said Harv Kalirai, Canadian analyst with New York-based financial analysis firm I.D.E.A.
In other prices, Canada's 10-year benchmark bond fell C$0.22 to C$105.43 to yield 6.501 percent. The U.S. 10-year bond rose 2/32 to yield 6.65 percent.
The negative spread between the two bonds narrowed to 15 basis points from 18 basis points at the close of trading on Monday.
The three-month cash T-bill traded with a yield of 2.97 percent against its U.S. equivalent which yielded 5.01 percent.

Canada's 30-year benchmark fell C$0.10 to C$112.37 to yield 7.007 percent. The U.S. 30-year bond traded unchanged to yield 6.90 percent. The spread between the bonds widened to 11 basis points from 10 basis points at Monday's close.

Canadian bonds firmed slightly last night following reports that the governing Liberals were on track to win a majority governent. The Liberals went on to win 155 of the 301 seats in Canada's Parliament in yesterday's elections, for a majority of just four seats.
The narrow size of the win provided little reason for the market to follow through on the initial gains, analysts said.

"I can't see the election as being a huge positive or a negative for the market. That's probably what's being reflected this morning," said Sheldon Dong, manager of fixed-income research with Midland Walwyn Capital Inc. "I don't sense a lot of activity or much reaction."

Analysts said volumes were light and some traders may be unwinding spread narrowing trades at the long end of the curve, which were placed in the expectation that a strong Liberal win would prompt a rally in the currency.
The Canadian dollar began North American trading almost unchanged from Monday's close.
